I also want to encourage Alaskans to stay safe and follow current @CDCgov #coronavirus guidance, which you can find on my website at https://t.co/QBM19uv8tv. Working together, we will get through the serious challenges facing our state and country. Stay well.

My staff and I will remain highly involved in these legislative efforts. We‚Äôre also in regular contact with our state health officials and elected officials, standing by to give them the assistance needed in containing and treating the #coronavirus.

I encouraged Senate leaders to prioritize addressing our challenges instead of taking a scheduled recess. We will stay in session next week to work on a larger economic aid & relief package to mitigate the impacts of this pandemic on individuals, families & businesses in Alaska.

In D.C., we‚Äôre working to ensure Alaska has the tools necessary for #coronavirus prevention & treatment. Last week, we passed an $8.3 billion emergency funding package that allocates¬†money to state, local & tribal health providers. These funds are already coming to Alaska.

Much has changed in our country in the last few weeks and it‚Äôs an uncertain time for many of us. But one thing is clear: Alaskans are the most resilient people anywhere and, working together, we can limit the spread and lessen the impact of this #coronavirus.

I want to extend my sincerest gratitude to the outstanding judges and their teams who worked in partnership with victim advocates to reach attorneys and let them know how their legal expertise can lift vulnerable women and children out of horrible situations.

When we launched the POWER Act several years ago, I envisioned an army of lawyers across the country donating their time and talent to defending survivors of violence. I believe we are on the cusp of making that vision a reality.

This week, I received some incredible news. In 2019, the federal judiciary held more than 100 POWER Act summits across the country, attended by more than 7,000 Americans ‚Äì lawyers and victims, alike.
üëâ https://t.co/NsmmpVasVb

The POWER Act mandates that each year, for four years, the Chief Judge of each Judicial District across the country hold at least one event promoting pro bono legal services. We held Alaska‚Äôs first event in Anchorage in August of 2019.

Experts agree that securing a lawyer for victims is the best way to get them out of their situation and to get them shelter, housing and medical care. That work in Alaska grew into my Pro Bono Work to Empower and Represent (POWER) Act, which was signed into law in 2018.

Sexual abuse & domestic violence are among our most pernicious social problems, and one of my top priorities as a Senator has been to support the needs of victims and survivors. Going back to my time as Alaska‚Äôs attorney general, I‚Äôve fought for expanded pro bono legal services.

A number of my Senate Democrat colleagues sent a letter to the nation‚Äôs top banks, urging them not to finance energy development on the North Slope. Sen. @lisamurkowski @repdonyoung and I sent a letter to the same banks to correct the record.

Elizabeth‚Äôs activism and accomplishments represent a shining example for all Americans ‚Äì an example that is now immortalized nationwide in a powerful way. Happy Elizabeth Peratrovich Day!

In so doing, she helped pass Alaska‚Äôs Anti-Discrimination Act of 1945, the 1st piece of legislation in the country ensuring equal rights for all people regardless of race. Today, we commemorate the 75th anniversary of that act, and the woman who helped make it happen.

Before Alaska was even a state, Elizabeth Peratrovich and her husband, Roy, along with the Alaska Native Sisterhood and Alaska Native Brotherhood, worked with Alaska‚Äôs territorial Legislature to end public facilities and local housing discrimination.

This week, the U.S. Mint released the long-awaited Sacagawea 1 Dollar Coin celebrating Elizabeth Peratrovich, a Tlingit woman from Petersburg and one of our nation‚Äôs greatest civil rights activists. https://t.co/CfHK44xqcX

In the Senate, we‚Äôve confirmed 188 federal judges ‚öñÔ∏è since @POTUS took office. Today, it was Alaska‚Äôs turn. I was glad to vote to confirm Joshua Kindred to serve as the next U.S. District Court Judge for our state.

I've introduced a bill w/ @ChrisVanHollen directing the administration to develop an in-depth report to Congress on the obstacles put in place by China to obstruct the free work of U.S. diplomats, officials, journalists and businesses in the country. 
‚û°Ô∏è https://t.co/plKadM31Ah https://t.co/CdKA9YupJS

This imbalance has been raised w/ the most senior Chinese officials for decades but Beijing has consistently failed to make good on its commitments to change. The US must insist on a bilateral relationship defined by something understood by every American: reciprocity & fairness.

The imbalance in the US-China relationship has reached a tipping point. American citizens & businesses operating in China face significant restriction, delay & censorship. Their Chinese counterparts, however, operate freely in the U.S., largely unencumbered by our government.

@SecElaineChao @DeptofDefense This grant will help restore the Port of Alaska‚Äôs status as a safe, cost-effective, reliable & resilient piece of infrastructure. I want to thank @SecElaineChao for recognizing the dire state of the Port and heeding the call of Alaskans by approving this much-needed PIDP grant.

@SecElaineChao The Port of Alaska is the only @DeptofDefense strategic seaport near the #Arctic‚Äîa fact we cannot overlook as sea ice recedes, traffic accelerates and our country‚Äôs adversaries, particularly Russia, grow their maritime capabilities in the region.

@SecElaineChao The Port of Alaska not only serves the most basic needs of a broad swath of Alaskans ‚Äì including fuel, food, construction materials, and other goods ‚Äì but also America‚Äôs security interests as an #Arctic nation.
